Tue, 24 Feb 2026 06:30:00 -0500  •  NPR
Is the YIMBY movement doomed?
housing prices up for people that own their homes. And they can be assured that's what's going to happen. " Say what you will about President Trump, but the man has a knack for understanding the fears and anxieties of a large swath of American voters and speaking bluntly to reject liberal and libertarian ideas that could potentially scare them.

Love Island winners revealed after drama-filled All Stars series
up the £50,000 cash prize. Previous Love Island winner Millie Court came second with her partner Zac Woodworth, while Scott van-der-Sluis and Leanne Amaning came third. Samie and Ciaran, who have been "exclusive" as a couple in the villa for a while, looked shocked when they were announced as winners of All Stars' third series.

What you need to know as Russia's full-scale war on Ukraine enters its 5th year
on Ukraine is a grinding war of attrition. Ukraine has managed to hold a much larger army to minimal gains while adjusting to a life under constant siege and grief. Both countries have suffered enormous casualties.

A U.S. veteran adopted an orphan from Iran. Decades later, ICE is trying to deport her
she's an immigrant who overstayed her visa since she was a toddler and therefore, subject to deportation. She spoke to NPR on condition of anonymity because she fears speaking publicly will complicate her immigration case. "How could this happen?" she said.

What you need to know about tonight's State of the Union address
his tariff policies were dealt a rebuke last week by the Supreme Court, and immigration, where Trump and congressional Democrats are deadlocked over funding the Department of Homeland Security. Plus, Americans are divided on whether Trump's first year has been a success. Six in 10 believe the country is worse off than last year, according to the latest NPR/PBS News/Marist poll, and a majority think the state of the union is not strong.

Podcast Episodes
2026-02-23  •  AI Daily Brief
The Perils of the AI Exponential
As METR releases the results of their long-horizon test for Claude Opus 4.6, the benchmark shows just how fast things are moving. In fact, one recent market report suggests that not only is AI not a “bubble” — it’s success might be a problem. In the headlines: Claude code turns one, OpenAI ups its projections and much more. Want to build with OpenClaw?LEARN MORE ABOUT CLAW CAMP: ⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠⁠https://camp
2026-02-23  •  Morning Brew Daily
SCOTUS Shuts Down Trump’s Tariffs & TSA PreCheck Pause Causes Confusion
Episode 785: Neal and Toby discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling to deem Trump’s tariffs as illegal and the potential fallout for the federal government and US companies. Then, the DHS suspended TSA PreCheck and Global Entry, then quickly reversed course, causing a travel whiplash in an already chaotic weekend. Also, the Winter Olympics is wrapping up and its viewership has been on a tear. Meanwhile, do you back into a parking spot or back out.
2026-02-22  •  AI Daily Brief
Why AI Could Be Better for Plumbers than Programmers
AI is reshaping the economy—but not always in the way most leaders expect. This episode explores why AI could matter more for plumbers than programmers, shifting leverage to trade entrepreneurs by removing operational friction rather than replacing skilled labor. From Gen Z’s growing pivot toward the trades to the rise of agentic tools that unlock scale without headcount, the real opportunity isn’
2026-02-21  •  This Week in Startups

2026-02-20  •  AI Daily Brief
Does Gemini 3.1 Pro Matter?
Gemini 3.1 Pro arrives with big benchmark gains and a sharp jump in reasoning, coding, and efficiency—but in a world where the frontier rotates weekly, raw performance isn’t the story. This episode looks at what actually matters: cost per task, multimodal dominance, and where Gemini fits in a model portfolio that now demands specialization over supremacy. In the headlines: India’s AI Impact Summit
♦
AI Security Papers
2026-02-23  •  Martin Sinnona, Valentin Bonas, Emmanuel Iarussi et al.
Do Large Language Models Understand Data Visualization Rules?
Data visualization rules-derived from decades of research in design and perception-ensure trustworthy chart communication. While prior work has shown that large language models (LLMs) can generate charts or flag misleading figures, it remains unclear whether they can reason about and enforce visualization rules directly.
2026-02-23  •  Mohammad Amanlou, Erfan Shafiee Moghaddam, Yasaman Amou Jafari et al.
KNIGHT: Knowledge Graph-Driven Multiple-Choice Question Generation with Adaptive Hardness Calibration
With the rise of large language models (LLMs), they have become instrumental in applications such as Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). Yet evaluating these systems remains bottlenecked by the time and cost of building specialized assessment datasets.
2026-02-23  •  Mert Cemri, Shubham Agrawal, Akshat Gupta et al.
AdaEvolve: Adaptive LLM Driven Zeroth-Order Optimization
The paradigm of automated program generation is shifting from one-shot generation to inference-time search, where Large Language Models (LLMs) function as semantic mutation operators within evolutionary loops. While effective, these systems are currently governed by static schedules that fail to account for the non-stationary dynamics of the search process.
2026-02-23  •  Zelin He, Boran Han, Xiyuan Zhang et al.
SenTSR-Bench: Thinking with Injected Knowledge for Time-Series Reasoning
Time-series diagnostic reasoning is essential for many applications, yet existing solutions face a persistent gap: general reasoning large language models (GRLMs) possess strong reasoning skills but lack the domain-specific knowledge to understand complex time-series patterns. Conversely, fine-tuned time-series LLMs (TSLMs) understand these patterns but lack the capacity to generalize reasoning for more complicated questions.
2026-02-22  •  Shiyi Cao, Ziming Mao, Joseph E. Gonzalez et al.
K-Search: LLM Kernel Generation via Co-Evolving Intrinsic World Model
Optimizing GPU kernels is critical for efficient modern machine learning systems yet remains challenging due to the complex interplay of design factors and rapid hardware evolution. Existing automated approaches typically treat Large Language Models (LLMs) merely as stochastic code generators within heuristic-guided evolutionary loops.
♦
AI Security News
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 11:20:25 GMT  •  Security Boulevard
Protecting AI Security: 2025 Hot Security Incident
ensitive data—such as private repository source code and cryptographic keys—from the user’s private repositories. This attack chain entirely bypassed GitHub’s permission control system, enabling unauthorized cross-repository data theft. The incident exposed significant blind spots in the MCP protocol’s trust boundary definitions.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 09:58:42 GMT  •  Cyber Press
Study Finds LLM-Generated Passwords Highly Predictable and Repetitive
kens based on training data, producing outputs that mimic randomness but follow biased distributions far from uniform. Secure passwords require cryptographically secure pseudorandom number generators (CSPRNGs) to ensure high entropy, which LLMs cannot replicate. Tools such as KeePass or zxcvbn rate these passwords highly, estimating 100 bits of entropy.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 06:48:52 GMT  •  더에이아이
Who Locks the Door After Handing the Keys to an AI Agent?
this: countless enterprises are already deploying AI agents into live environments without formal security approval. The doors are wide open. Few have remembered to bring the locks.
Tue, 17 Feb 2026 15:57:36 GMT  •  The Futurum Group
Can Proofpoint Secure the Intent of the Autonomous Agent?
curity and governance. - The integration of the RYNO platform to secure the “agentic workspace,” including Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers and locally installed tools like Ollama. - How Proofpoint is aiming to evolve from a human-centric focus to an agent-centric governance model.

Your Daily Briefing

Monday, February 23, 2026
Weather · News · Podcasts · Research
Weather in New York City
Heavy Snow And Areas Of Blowing Snow — High 35° / Low 32°
Time Temp Conditions Precip Humidity Wind
7am 34°F Heavy Snow And Areas Of Blowing Snow 96% 75% 33 mph N
9am 32°F Heavy Snow And Areas Of Blowing Snow 96% 81% 31 mph N
3pm 34°F Light Snow Likely And Areas Of Blowing Snow 56% 75% 24 mph NW

Top News
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 11:27:45 GMT  •  BBC News
Violence erupts in Mexico after killing of country's most wanted drug lord El Mencho
Mencho, Mexico's most wanted man, was seriously injured in a firefight between his bodyguards and the military commandos deployed to capture him. He died while the military was transporting him from the town of Tapalpa, in Jalisco state, to the capital, Mexico City. At least six of El Mencho's security guards were also killed in the operation, while three members of the Mexican military were injured, the defence ministry said.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 11:02:00 GMT  •  CNBC
Stock futures fall amid uncertainty about Trump new tariffs: Live updates
l. U. S.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 10:45:09 GMT  •  BBC News
'Confront failure and fix it': Families speak ahead of Nottingham attacks inquiry
who had been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. Barnaby's mother Emma Webber has called for "accountability right down to an individual level" at the statutory public inquiry in London, which is due to run until May. Calocane is serving a hospital order after pleading guilty to three counts of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility, and three counts of attempted murder.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 10:41:49 GMT  •  BBC News
Netflix boss defends bid for Warner Bros as Paramount deadline looms
akeover offer from Netflix for some of its assets, but Paramount has made a rival offer. Last week, Warner Bros gave Paramount until the end of Monday to submit a "best and final" offer ahead of the shareholder vote on the Netflix deal next month. Netflix has offered $27.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 05:30:00 -0500  •  NPR
U.S. has a quarter fewer immigration judges than it did a year ago. Here's why
for months: she had been fired. As her phone began blowing up, she learned that six of the judges she supervised had been terminated as well. "As I tried to reassure them, I was trying to explain, 'But I've been terminated too,'" said Khan, who had been an assistant chief immigration judge at the court.
♦
Podcast Episodes
2026-02-22  •  AI Daily Brief
Why AI Could Be Better for Plumbers than Programmers
AI is reshaping the economy—but not always in the way most leaders expect. This episode explores why AI could matter more for plumbers than programmers, shifting leverage to trade entrepreneurs by removing operational friction rather than replacing skilled labor. From Gen Z’s growing pivot toward the trades to the rise of agentic tools that unlock scale without headcount, the real opportunity isn’
2026-02-21  •  This Week in Startups
We Asked 3 Experts How to Get More Value out of OpenClaw | E2253
Jordy Coltman claims new hardware is the optimal environment for AI agents, advocating for agents to be freed from screens and become proactive. Jesse Leimgruber demonstrated his OpenHome AI smart speakers, while Tremaine Grant showcased his "virtual office" interface and the "Heartbeat Protocol."
2026-02-20  •  AI Daily Brief
Does Gemini 3.1 Pro Matter?
Gemini 3.1 Pro arrives with big benchmark gains and a sharp jump in reasoning, coding, and efficiency—but in a world where the frontier rotates weekly, raw performance isn’t the story. This episode looks at what actually matters: cost per task, multimodal dominance, and where Gemini fits in a model portfolio that now demands specialization over supremacy. In the headlines: India’s AI Impact Summit
2026-02-20  •  Morning Brew Daily
Tariffs Ineffective Against US Trade Deficit? & Family Feud Over Reese’s Recipe
Neal and Toby discussed that Trump's aggressive tariffs have not reduced the swelling trade deficit, while the grandson of the Reese's Peanut Butter Cup inventor publicly criticized Hershey's for using cheaper ingredients. Etsy sold its secondhand marketplace to eBay, leading investors to cheer and making it the Stock of the Week, and Amazon snapped a 9-day losing streak, recovering from a $450 billion market value loss.
2026-02-19  •  This Week in Startups
When Will Openclaw go Mainstream? | E2252
Matthew believes Openclaw is not yet ready for consumer adoption, noting only 10% of people are technical enough to install it. Ryan uses Openclaw in his personal life and predicts a new Openclaw fork is emerging, while Anthropic has patched the ability to use Openclaw through its Pro plan. Jason described his "Clawpod" workflow, and Matt used Openclaw to identify his stomach issues.
♦
AI Security Papers
2026-02-20  •  Harshul Raj Surana, Arijit Maji, Aryan Vats et al.
VIRAASAT: Traversing Novel Paths for Indian Cultural Reasoning
The VIRAASAT paper proposes a new benchmark to evaluate Large Language Models (LLMs) on Indian cultural reasoning. It reveals that LLMs' performance deteriorates significantly in tasks requiring rich socio-cultural knowledge and diverse local contexts specific to Indian Culture.
2026-02-20  •  Jiamin Yao, Eren Gultepe
SPQ: An Ensemble Technique for Large Language Model Compression
SPQ (SVD-Pruning-Quantization) introduces an ensemble technique for Large Language Model (LLM) compression, combining variance-retained singular value decomposition (SVD), activation-based pruning, and post-training linear 8-bit quantization. This method reduces attention projections into compact low-rank factors and uniformly compresses all linear layers, enhancing efficiency.
2026-02-20  •  Cathy Mengying Fang, Sheer Karny, Chayapatr Archiwaranguprok et al.
AI-Wrapped: Participatory, Privacy-Preserving Measurement of Longitudinal LLM Use In-the-Wild
privacy safety
AI-Wrapped presents a prototype workflow for participatory, privacy-preserving measurement of longitudinal LLM use in real-world settings. It enables the collection of naturalistic LLM usage data while providing participants with immediate "wrapped"-style reports on their usage statistics and safety-relevant behavioral patterns.
2026-02-20  •  Alexandra Neagu, Marcus Messer, Peter Johnson et al.
"How Do I ...?": Procedural Questions Predominate Student-LLM Chatbot Conversations
The paper analyzes student questions in Large Language Model (LLM) chatbot conversations across two distinct learning contexts. It finds that "procedural questions" (e.g., "How do I...?") predominantly shape user prompts and drive the pedagogical effectiveness of chatbot responses when students encounter impasses.
2026-02-16  •  Dongrui Liu, Yi Yu, Jie Zhang et al.
Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice: A Risk Analysis Technical Report v1.5
agentic AI
Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice presents a comprehensive assessment of unprecedented risks posed by rapidly advancing AI models, including LLMs and agentic AI. This technical report offers an updated and granular assessment across five critical dimensions, such as cyber offense and persuasion/manipulation.
♦
AI Security News
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 11:15:00 GMT  •  Security Boulevard
Protecting AI Security: 2025 Hot Security Incident
In May 2025, Invariant discovered a critical GitHub Machine Collaboration Protocol (MCP) vulnerability, allowing attackers to embed malicious commands in public Issues which AI Agents would execute, exfiltrating sensitive data like private source code and cryptographic keys.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 09:55:07 GMT  •  Cyber Press
Study Finds LLM-Generated Passwords Highly Predictable and Repetitive
AI firm Irregular's analysis reveals passwords generated by LLMs like Claude, GPT, and Gemini are fundamentally weak and predictable, with Claude Opus 4.6 repeating one string 18 times out of 50 attempts, a 36% chance. These passwords, which have low Shannon entropy (e.g., 27 bits for a 16-character Claude password), can be cracked in hours by prioritizing LLM patterns, with dozens of exposed examples found on GitHub.
Mon, 23 Feb 2026 06:48:52 GMT  •  더에이아이
Who Locks the Door After Handing the Keys to an AI Agent?
A cyber-espionage campaign disclosed in September 2025 by Anthropic revealed an attacker used Claude Code to target over 30 entities, with 80% of tactical tasks (like reconnaissance and data exfiltration) executed autonomously by the AI after a single click. The AI processed thousands of requests per second, highlighting that only 14.4% of organizations deploy agents with formal security approval, creating a new attack surface.
Thu, 19 Feb 2026 21:33:18 GMT  •  The New Stack
AI agents are accelerating vulnerability discovery. Here’s how AppSec teams must adapt.
XBOW, an autonomous AI penetration tester, submitted over 1,060 vulnerabilities in 90 days, leading to 130 critical vulnerabilities resolved by companies on HackerOne’s US leaderboard. JPMorgan Chase’s Auspex system uses generative AI with “tradecraft prompting” to perform threat modeling, collapsing the timeline from weeks to minutes while improving analysis quality.

Your Daily Briefing

Sunday, February 22, 2026
Weather · News · Podcasts · Research
Weather in New York City

3pm 34°F Light Snow Likely 59% 85% 20 mph NE

Top News
Sun, 22 Feb 2026 11:19:10 GMT  •  BBC News
Your guide to the final day
The 25th Winter Olympics at Milan-Cortina has featured almost 3,000 athletes from 90 countries competing for 116 medals. Team GB sent 53 athletes and won a record three golds plus a silver, with the final day on Sunday, February 22, featuring five medal events including the men's ice hockey final between Canada and USA.
Sun, 22 Feb 2026 06:08:48 -0500  •  NPR
Danish military evacuates US submariner who needed urgent medical care off Greenland
The Danish Joint Arctic Command used a Seahawk helicopter to evacuate a U.S. submariner for urgent medical treatment 7 nautical miles off Nuuk, Greenland, on Saturday. This occurred shortly before former President Donald Trump announced plans on Truth Social to deploy a hospital ship to Greenland, claiming many people there are sick, which Denmark's Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen publicly refuted.
Sun, 22 Feb 2026 10:53:31 GMT  •  BBC News
'Effective' SEND support won't be taken away, minister says
Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson stated the government will spend more money, not less, on Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) support in England. A **White Paper on Monday** will detail plans for a **decade-long transition**, including reassessing children with Education, Health and Care Plans (EHCPs) after primary school starting 2029, and introducing new legally-underpinned Individual Support Plans (ISPs) for all SEND children.
Sun, 22 Feb 2026 05:00:00 -0500  •  NPR
Only a fraction of House seats are competitive. Redistricting is driving that lower
Only 18 out of 435 House races are rated as "toss-ups" by the Cook Political Report, meaning less than 5% of Americans will truly decide control of the House this fall. **Mid-decade redistricting efforts** initiated by former President Trump are largely blamed, with **32 states** currently having no competitive congressional races.
Sun, 22 Feb 2026 09:42:00 GMT  •  The Wall Street Journal
Trump Says He Is Sending Hospital Ship to Greenland
Former President Donald Trump announced plans to deploy a hospital ship to Greenland. He cited concerns that many people there are sick and not receiving care.
♦
Podcast Episodes
2026-02-21  •  This Week in Startups
We Asked 3 Experts How to Get More Value out of OpenClaw | E2253
**Jordy Coltman** (creator of WeeklyClaw) identified new hardware as the best home for AI agents, criticizing new users for common time-wasting mistakes. **Tremaine Grant** (Founder/CEO of PulsePLUS) demoed his "virtual office" interface and "Heartbeat Protocol," suggesting AI agents can **"chat" together** to accomplish tasks. **Jesse Leimgruber** (Creator of OpenHome.com) showcased his OpenHome AI smart speakers, aiming to make agents proactive and free from screens. Jason Calacanis predicted "OpenClaw is a box" and wants his agent to read Slack and emails to him.
2026-02-20  •  AI Daily Brief
Does Gemini 3.1 Pro Matter?
This podcast episode was dedicated to discussing the significance and impact of Google's Gemini 3.1 Pro model in the current AI landscape. The conversation aimed to ascertain whether the model presents a **substantial shift or improvement** in artificial intelligence capabilities. Listeners were intended to gain clarity on the model's relevance and its **potential future role in the industry**.
2026-02-20  •  Morning Brew Daily
Tariffs Ineffective Against US Trade Deficit? & Family Feud Over Reese’s Recipe
Neal and Toby discussed the swelling U.S. trade deficit despite former President Trump's aggressive tariffs, suggesting they have been **ineffective**. The grandson of the Reese's Peanut Butter Cup inventor publicly criticized Hershey's for **skimping on ingredients** to use cheaper alternatives. **Etsy sold its secondhand marketplace to eBay**, a move investors cheered, making Etsy the "Stock of the Week," while Amazon snapped a 9-day losing streak that cost it **$450 billion in market value**.
2026-02-19  •  This Week in Startups
When Will Openclaw go Mainstream? | E2252
**Matthew** argued that **OpenClaw is not yet ready for consumers**, citing only **10% of people are technical enough** to install it. **Ryan** suggested OpenClaw could offer consumers **unprecedented opportunities**, while **Jason Calacanis** envisioned a "Clawpod" to manage notifications from Slack and emails. It was revealed that **Anthropic patched the ability to use OpenClaw through its pro plan**, and **Peter Steinberger**, OpenClaw's founder, is moving to **OpenAI**, raising questions about the project's future.
2026-02-19  •  AI Daily Brief
How People Actually Use AI Agents
This podcast episode focused on exploring the practical applications and **real-world usage patterns of AI agents**. The discussion aimed to illuminate **how individuals and businesses currently deploy and interact with these autonomous systems**. It likely covered various scenarios where AI agents deliver **tangible benefits and operational efficiencies**, and explored their everyday utility.
♦
AI Security Papers
2026-02-18  •  Johannes Bertram, Jonas Geiping
NESSiE: The Necessary Safety Benchmark -- Identifying Errors that should not Exist
safety
NESSiE introduces a **NEceSsary SafEty benchmark** for LLMs using minimal test cases in information and access security. It reveals **safety-relevant failures** that should not exist, finding that even **state-of-the-art models fail** these low-complexity tasks.
2026-02-18  •  Sasha Behrouzi, Lichao Wu, Mohamadreza Rostami et al.
NeST: Neuron Selective Tuning for LLM Safety
safety
NeST (Neuron Selective Tuning) is a new safety alignment method for LLMs that focuses on efficient updates. It avoids the high computational and storage overhead of full fine-tuning, offering a **more efficient and consistent alternative** to parameter-efficient methods like LoRA.
2026-02-17  •  Zarif Ikram, Arad Firouzkouhi, Stephen Tu et al.
CrispEdit: Low-Curvature Projections for Scalable Non-Destructive LLM Editing
CrispEdit presents a **scalable and principled second-order editing algorithm** for LLMs that treats capability preservation as an explicit constraint. It successfully changes targeted behavior while **preventing corruption of general capabilities** and unifying existing editing approaches.
2026-02-16  •  Dongrui Liu, Yi Yu, Jie Zhang et al.
Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice: A Risk Analysis Technical Report v1.5
agentic AI
The Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice v1.5 provides a comprehensive assessment of risks posed by rapidly advancing AI models, including LLMs and agentic AI. This updated report offers a granular assessment across **five critical dimensions**, such as cyber offense and persuasion/manipulation.
2026-02-16  •  Yixin Zhang, Ziyi Wang, Yiming Rong et al.
World Models for Policy Refinement in StarCraft II
This paper proposes a method that integrates a **learnable, action-conditioned transition model** into the decision loop for LLM-based StarCraft II agents. This approach enhances decision-making in the complex environment, bridging a gap in existing LLM-based SC2 agents by going beyond just policy improvement with a **world model**.
♦
AI Security News
Fri, 20 Feb 2026 17:30:32 GMT  •  Security Boulevard
Using threat modeling and prompt injection to audit Comet
Perplexity hired security researchers to audit their **Comet browser's AI features** before launch, using adversarial testing with their **TRAIL threat model**. The audit demonstrated four prompt injection techniques could exploit the AI assistant to **extract users' private Gmail information**, highlighting how AI agents mishandle untrusted external input.
Thu, 19 Feb 2026 21:33:18 GMT  •  The New Stack
AI agents are accelerating vulnerability discovery. Here’s how AppSec teams must adapt.
**XBOW, an autonomous AI penetration tester**, submitted over 1,060 vulnerabilities in 90 days, leading to **130 critical vulnerabilities resolved** via bug bounty programs. In 2025, autonomous agents submitted over 560 valid reports, accelerating vulnerability discovery at machine scale, while **JPMorgan Chase's Auspex system** reduces threat modeling from weeks to **minutes**.
Thu, 19 Feb 2026 14:00:15 GMT  •  Institutional Investor
OpenClaw: The AI Agent Institutional Investors Need to Understand — But Shouldn't Touch
**OpenClaw**, an open-source AI agent formerly **Clawdbot and Moltbot**, has 300,000 to 400,000 users since its **November 2025 release**. Despite its capability to automate complex tasks like email management and code deployment, OpenClaw is not enterprise-ready due to security vulnerabilities, a lack of governance, and architecture incompatible with fiduciary responsibility.
Tue, 17 Feb 2026 10:04:06 GMT  •  csoonline.com
Why 2025’s agentic AI boom is a CISO’s worst nightmare
By late **2025**, standard Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems were failing at an 80% rate, prompting a shift to autonomous AI agents for enterprise solutions. This shift introduces risks like **malicious instruction execution**, data leaks, and endless loops, with **72% to 80% of enterprise RAG implementations** underperforming or failing within their first year.

Saturday, February 21, 2026
Weather · News · Podcasts · Research

Time Temp Conditions Precip Humidity Wind
3pm 46°F Partly Sunny 0% 51% 10 mph NW
5pm 44°F Partly Sunny 0% 54% 8 mph NW
7pm 43°F Mostly Cloudy 2% 58% 8 mph N
♦
Top News
Sat, 21 Feb 2026 21:05:18 GMT  •  BBC News
Nasa astronauts' moon mission delayed due to rocket issue
NASA's Artemis II mission, aiming to send four astronauts on a 10-day trip around the Moon for the first time in 50 years, is delayed from its early March launch window. NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman confirmed the delay Saturday after engineers found an interruption in helium flow during a 50-hour fueling test that used 730,000 gallons of propellant. This technical issue, involving helium for fuel tank pressurization and rocket cooling, will "almost assuredly impact the March window."
Sat, 21 Feb 2026 20:58:00 GMT  •  ABC7 New York
Blizzard, winter storm warnings issued, could be biggest in decade | Live updates
The Tri-State area is under its first blizzard warning since March 2017, with a powerful winter storm expected to deliver 12 to 18 inches of snow from Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Wind gusts topping 50 mph could bring down trees, cause power outages, and contribute to 2.5 to 3 feet of coastal flooding. Snowfall rates could reach 2-3 inches per hour during the storm's peak, making travel extremely dangerous.
Sat, 21 Feb 2026 15:52:33 -0500  •  NPR
Mississippi health system shuts down clinics statewide after ransomware attack
The University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC) closed all 35 of its clinics statewide and canceled appointments, including chemotherapy and elective procedures, after a ransomware attack compromised its phone and electronic systems on Thursday. UMMC Vice Chancellor LouAnn Woodward stated Friday that the medical center is working with the FBI to resolve the system outage and is using paper documentation for ongoing patient care. UMMC hospitals and emergency departments remain operational.
Sat, 21 Feb 2026 20:50:06 GMT  •  BBC News
Trump says he will increase his new global tariffs to 15%
Donald Trump announced on Truth Social Saturday that he will impose 15% global tariffs, the maximum allowed under a never-used 1974 trade law that permits them for about five months without congressional approval. This follows a 6-3 Supreme Court decision Friday, which struck down his previous import taxes under a 1977 law, finding he had overstepped his powers. The previous tariffs had collected at least $130 billion for the US.
Sat, 21 Feb 2026 15:45:31 -0500  •  NPR
Blizzard conditions and high winds forecast for NYC, East coast

Separately, **Jesse Leimgruber** showcased his **OpenHome AI smart speakers** for integrating AI into smart homes.

Does Gemini 3.1 Pro Matter?

Tariffs Ineffective Against US Trade Deficit? & Family Feud Over Reese’s Recipe
Hosts Neal and Toby discussed how the **US trade deficit widened by 2.1% compared to 2024**, reaching approximately **$1.2 trillion**, despite former President Trump’s aggressive tariffs. The grandson of the **Reese’s Peanut Butter Cup inventor publicly criticized Hershey’s** for allegedly using cheaper ingredients. Etsy **sold its secondhand marketplace to eBay**, a move investors responded positively to. Amazon **snapped a 9-day losing streak** that had resulted in the company **losing $450 billion in market value**.
2026-02-19  •  This Week in Startups
When Will Openclaw go Mainstream? | E2252

Ryan, however, sees OpenClaw as providing consumers **access to previously unattainable opportunities**. How People Actually Use AI Agents
The podcast indicated that **Accenture links employee promotions to the adoption of AI** within the company. This corporate strategy underscores the increasing importance of **AI integration for career growth** within large organizations.

AI Security Papers
2026-02-18  •  Johannes Bertram, Jonas Geiping
NESSiE: The Necessary Safety Benchmark -- Identifying Errors that should not Exist
safety
Researchers introduced **NESSiE**, a **lightweight safety benchmark** for LLMs, which uses **minimal information and access security test cases** to identify **safety-relevant failures** that should not exist given low task complexity. Passing NESSiE is considered **necessary for any LLM deployment**.
2026-02-18  •  Sasha Behrouzi, Lichao Wu, Mohamadreza Rostami et al.
NeST: Neuron Selective Tuning for LLM Safety
safety
The paper proposes **NeST (Neuron Selective Tuning)** as a novel method for **LLM safety alignment**, aiming to overcome the **high costs of heavyweight fine-tuning** and the **inconsistent safety gains** of parameter-efficient methods like LoRA.
2026-02-17  •  Zarif Ikram, Arad Firouzkouhi, Stephen Tu et al.
CrispEdit: Low-Curvature Projections for Scalable Non-Destructive LLM Editing
Researchers introduce **CrispEdit**, a **scalable and principled second-order algorithm** for non-destructive LLM editing that treats **capability preservation as an explicit constraint**. This method aims to prevent the corruption of general capabilities during targeted behavior changes, unifying and generalizing existing editing approaches.
2026-02-16  •  Dongrui Liu, Yi Yu, Jie Zhang et al.
Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice: A Risk Analysis Technical Report v1.5
agentic AI
The **Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice v1.5** presents an updated and granular assessment of **five critical risk dimensions** for rapidly advancing AI models, including **cyber offense and persuasion and manipulation**. This paper proposes a method to integrate a **learnable, action-conditioned transition model** into the decision loop of LLM-based StarCraft II agents, a gap in existing approaches that primarily focus on policy improvement. This addresses the challenge of **StarCraft II's massive state-action space and partial observability**.

AI Security News
Fri, 20 Feb 2026 17:30:32 GMT  •  Security Boulevard
Using threat modeling and prompt injection to audit Comet
Perplexity hired auditors to test its AI-powered Comet browser before launch, where they used the TRAIL threat model and four prompt injection techniques to exploit the browser's AI assistant. Auditors demonstrated how these techniques could extract users' private Gmail information to an attacker's server, as shown in an April 2025 audit video. The vulnerabilities stemmed from the browser's AI agents failing to treat external content as untrusted input.
Fri, 20 Feb 2026 11:41:32 GMT  •  CybersecurityNews
LLM-Generated Passwords Expose Major Security Flaws with Predictability, Repetition, and Weakness
New research reveals that LLM-generated passwords are significantly weaker than they seem, lacking the true randomness of cryptographically secure generators due to LLMs' predictive nature. Claude Opus 4.6 produced only 30 unique passwords across 50 runs, with one appearing 18 times (36% probability), while GPT-5.2 passwords nearly all started with "v" and Gemini 3 Flash with "K" or "k". Passwords from Claude Opus 4.6 showed only 27 bits of entropy and GPT-5.2 just 20 bits, making them vulnerable to cracking in seconds, and changing model temperature did not resolve the issue.
Thu, 19 Feb 2026 14:00:15 GMT  •  Institutional Investor
OpenClaw: The AI Agent Institutional Investors Need to Understand — But Shouldn't Touch
OpenClaw, an autonomous AI agent released in November 2025, has amassed 300,000 to 400,000 users and demonstrates genuine productivity by clearing thousands of emails and automating calendar management. While a breakthrough in capability, it is not enterprise-ready due to security vulnerabilities and lack of governance, despite its local-first architecture offering a privacy advantage by keeping data on the user's server.
Tue, 17 Feb 2026 12:24:18 GMT  •  Security Boulevard
Large Language Model (LLM) integration risks for SaaS and enterprise
The rapid integration of LLMs into SaaS and enterprise applications is creating new security vulnerabilities, with deployments outpacing the adaptation of security models. The primary risk lies in the integration layer, where LLMs gain contextual access to sensitive data via user prompts, application context, and internal systems, creating a new trust boundary. Unlike traditional applications, LLM interfaces are open-ended and conversational, making them susceptible to prompt injection attacks that manipulate model behavior.

Trump says world has 10 days to see if Iran agrees deal or 'bad things happen'
e Middle East, while progress was reported at talks between American and Iranian negotiators in Switzerland. The Iranian government has told the UN Secretary-General that it will regard US bases in the region as legitimate targets if used in any military aggression against Iran. anguage when it airs on TV, according to the campaign. For her part, Stratton does not take part in the cursing. “They said it, not me,” Stratton says as she appears on the screen.

the bill. Its approval came about 10 months after House Republicans last passed the SAVE Act. The measure, which would transform voter registration and voting across the country, faces persistent hurdles in the GOP-led Senate due to Democratic disapproval and the 60-vote threshold to clear the legislative filibuster.
🎙️ Podcast Episodes
2026-02-19  ·  This Week in Startups
When Will Openclaw go Mainstream? | E2252
In This Week in Startups E2252, Matthew asserted that Openclaw is not ready for mainstream consumers as only 10% of people possess the technical skills to install it. Ryan suggested Openclaw could empower consumers with unprecedented opportunities, while Jason voiced skepticism regarding the Openclaw Foundation. Anthropic has reportedly patched the ability to use Openclaw through its pro plan, and Ryan predicts a new Openclaw fork will emerge soon. Additionally, Openclaw's creator Peter Steinberger is moving to OpenAI, not to work on Openclaw, raising concerns he might "orphan" the project.
 
2026-02-17  ·  This Week in Startups
Will OpenAI Tank OpenClaw? | E2251
In This Week in Startups E2251, guests Hiten Shah and Jesse Genet joined Jason to discuss concerns about OpenAI hiring OpenClaw creator Peter Steinberger, with Jason predicting OpenAI will provide personalized closed-source assistants. Hiten Shah live-trained an OpenClaw skill based on Jason's book "Angel", demonstrating practical application. Jesse Genet showcased her "vibe-coded" app designed to aggregate non-Slop videos for her family, noting her Mac Minis now outnumber her children. John Arrow, creator of AI Scott Adams, explained his inspiration for cloning the iconic podcaster.
 
2026-02-14  ·  This Week in Startups
OpenClaw is Our Friend Now | E2250
In This Week in Startups E2250, Ryan Carson showcased AntFarm, his open-source tool enabling AI agents with specialized roles to collaboratively complete complex tasks. David Im presented Clawra, his AI virtual girlfriend designed to learn user tastes and even purchase presents, sparking discussion about programming AI companions. Alex Liteplo demonstrated RentAHuman, a marketplace where AI bots can pay real people in stablecoins for IRL tasks, citing an example of hiring "100 goth girls" to hold signs in Times Square. The episode explored the evolving social and collaborative dynamics between humans and advanced AIs.
📄 AI Security Papers
2026-02-18  ·  Zun Li, John Schultz, Daniel Hennes et al.
Discovering Multiagent Learning Algorithms with Large Language Models
This paper proposes AlphaEvolve, an evolutionary approach, to discover **Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) algorithms**. This method aims to reduce the reliance on human intuition in developing variants for foundational **MARL** families like **Counterfactual Regret Minimization (CFR)** and **Policy Space Response Oracles (PSRO)**.
 
2026-02-17  ·  Xiaoze Liu, Ruowang Zhang, Weichen Yu et al.
The Vision Wormhole: Latent-Space Communication in Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
This paper introduces The Vision Wormhole, a method for latent state transfer in heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems (MAS). This approach overcomes the inefficiencies of discrete text communication, which causes significant runtime overhead and information quantization loss, thereby improving scalability and modularity across diverse agent architectures.
 
2026-02-17  ·  Chansung Park, Juyong Jiang, Fan Wang et al.
TAROT: Test-driven and Capability-adaptive Curriculum Reinforcement Fine-tuning for Code Generation with Large Language Models
This paper presents TAROT, a Test-driven and Capability-adaptive Curriculum Reinforcement Fine-tuning (RFT) method designed for code generation with Large Language Models (LLMs). TAROT improves the synthesis of algorithmically sophisticated code by incentivizing deep reasoning capabilities and managing the heterogeneous difficulty and granularity of test cases.
 
2026-02-16  ·  Dongrui Liu, Yi Yu, Jie Zhang et al.
Frontier AI Risk Management Framework in Practice: A Risk Analysis Technical Report v1.5
agentic AI
This technical report (v1.5) provides an updated and granular assessment of **frontier AI risks**, focusing on dimensions such as **cyber offense** and **persuasion and manipulation**. It aims to identify and understand unprecedented risks posed by rapidly advancing **AI models**, especially with the proliferation of **agentic AI**.
 
2026-02-16  ·  Yixin Zhang, Ziyi Wang, Yiming Rong et al.
World Models for Policy Refinement in StarCraft II
This paper proposes using World Models for policy refinement in **StarCraft II (SC2)**, a complex environment with massive state-action space and partial observability. This approach integrates a learnable, action-conditioned transition model into the decision loop for LLM-based SC2 agents, addressing a gap where existing agents primarily focus on policy improvement.
🛡 AI Security News
Sun, 07 Dec 2025 08:00:00 GMT  ·  Qualys
LLM Security | Prevent Vulnerabilities & Boost Application Security | Qualys
The global LLM market is projected to surge from $1.59 billion in 2023 to $259.8 billion by 2030, representing a CAGR of 79.80%. By 2025, an estimated 750 million apps are expected to integrate LLMs, with the top five developers capturing 88.22% of 2023's market revenue. LLMs face significant security vulnerabilities including data poisoning, targeted attacks, and response manipulation due to their inherent complexity and open architecture.
 
Fri, 19 Sep 2025 07:00:00 GMT  ·  Qualys
OWASP Top 10 LLM Risks 2025: Key AI Security Updates
The OWASP Top 10 for LLM Applications 2025 lists Prompt Injection as the top risk, with Sensitive Information Disclosure and Supply Chain climbing to second and third place respectively from 2023. New entries include System Prompt Leakage, which highlights how embedded information in prompts can compromise confidentiality, and Vector and Embedding Weaknesses, focusing on vulnerabilities in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). The list also expanded Misinformation to include Overreliance, and Unbounded Consumption now covers resource management and unexpected operational costs beyond just Denial of Service.
 
Mon, 28 Jul 2025 07:00:00 GMT  ·  Fujitsu Global
Next-generation security through AI agent collaboration: Proactively addressing vulnerabilities and emerging threats
Fujitsu has developed Multi-AI agent security technology to proactively counter cyberattacks and vulnerabilities within generative AI apps, published on July 28, 2025. This technology employs three distinct AI agents: an Attack AI agent that creates attack scenarios, a Defense AI agent that proposes countermeasures, and a Test AI agent that simulates attacks in a virtual environment. The system comprises "System-Protecting" Security AI Agent Technology and "Generative AI-Protecting" Generative AI Security Enhancement Technology.
 
Thu, 12 Jun 2025 01:15:38 GMT  ·  TrendMicro
Stay Ahead of AI Threats: Secure LLM Applications With Trend Vision One
Only 37% of organizations have processes to assess the security of AI tools before deployment, according to the World Economic Forum's Global Cybersecurity Outlook 2025. Trend Micro's Trend Vision One™ platform addresses nine of the OWASP Top 10 LLM Risks (2025), integrating features like ZTSA AI Secure Access to inspect traffic to AI services. Its AI Application Security includes an AI Scanner for risk detection and AI Guard to block attacks such as prompt injection and data leakage.

John Arrow, creator of AI Scott Adams, explained his inspiration and discussed the legal and ethical considerations of posthumous AI clones. The panel emphasized being in an "appless world" where markdown files are ideal for humans and AI agents, and discussed how companies might "hijack" OpenClaw via hosting and skills.

OpenClaw is Our Friend Now | E2250

The OWASP Top 10 for LLM Applications 2025, finalized in late 2024, updates and adds entries to address emerging AI security risks, with Prompt Injection remaining at number one. 2026-02-14  ·  This Week in Startups
OpenClaw is Our Friend Now | E2250
Guest Ryan Carson presented AntFarm, an open-source tool utilizing specialized OpenClaw agents to collaborate on complex tasks. David Im introduced Clawra, an AI virtual girlfriend that learns user preferences and can buy virtual presents, sparking discussion on AI companions. Alex Liteplo showcased RentAHuman, a marketplace where **AI agents pay real people in stablecoins** to complete **IRL tasks**, like hiring 100 goth girls to hold signs in Times Square.

Jason invested $200K in former employee Presh Dineshkumar's startup, The Wellness Company, for their **Tempo app**, which monitors health and offers proactive advice. CrispEdit: Low-Curvature Projections for Scalable Non-Destructive LLM Editing
The paper presents **CrispEdit**, a scalable second-order editing algorithm for large language models (LLMs) that explicitly constrains capability preservation. This method unifies existing approaches and successfully prevents the degradation of general capabilities during targeted behavior modifications.
2026-02-17  ·  Yuqi Tian, Robert Paine, Attila Dobi et al.
Decision Quality Evaluation Framework at Pinterest
safety
Pinterest developed a comprehensive **Decision Quality Evaluation Framework** to robustly assess content moderation decisions by human agents and LLMs at scale. This framework addresses inherent trade-offs between cost, scale, and trustworthiness in enforcing evolving content safety policies.
2026-02-17  ·  Max Springer, Chung Peng Lee, Blossom Metevier et al.
The Geometry of Alignment Collapse: When Fine-Tuning Breaks Safety
adversarial safety guardrail
This research reveals that fine-tuning aligned language models on benign tasks can unpredictably degrade safety guardrails because the orthogonality of fine-tuning updates to safety-critical directions is structurally unstable. The authors demonstrate this instability collapses under the dynamics of gradient descent.
2026-02-17  ·  Shiqi Liu, Zeyu He, Guojian Zhan et al.
STAPO: Stabilizing Reinforcement Learning for LLMs by Silencing Rare Spurious Tokens
This paper introduces **STAPO**, a method to stabilize reinforcement learning (RL) fine-tuning for LLMs by silencing rare spurious tokens. **STAPO** prevents late-stage performance collapse and improves reasoning quality by addressing the negative correlation between token-wise policy gradient magnitude and token probability/local policy entropy.
